author: By Hamilton Matthew Masters and Giulia Heyward
title: After Covid Diagnosis, a Conservative Radio Host Sends a New Message
description: The Tennessee radio host, Phil Valentine, said he was among those who did not need to get vaccinated. Now his struggle with the virus is sparking its own discussion.
content: NASHVILLE — Mark Valentine knows that his brother Phil Valentine, a prominent conservative radio host who scoffed at the need to get vaccinated, has had a big impact on how his listeners have viewed the pandemic and their own response to it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Thomas
title: U.S. broadcast coverage includes swimming, softball and taekwondo.
description: Katie Ledecky, the defending Olympic champion, faces a true challenger in swimming.
content: Here are some highlights of U.S. broadcast coverage for Sunday evening and overnight, including women’s swimming, taekwondo and the next game for the seemingly unstoppable softball team. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: U.S. General Won’t Commit to Ending Airstrikes on Taliban
description: With the militants making advances across Afghanistan, the top American general there suggested that airstrikes may continue, even with the U.S. troop pullout largely completed.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The top American general overseeing operations in Afghanistan declined to say Sunday night whether U.S. airstrikes against the Taliban would end Aug. 31, the date previously given by officials as a cutoff for such attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: Taekwondo Is Path to Medals for Countries That Rarely Get Them
description: Ivory Coast and Jordan won their first-ever Olympic golds, thanks to taekwondo, as did Taiwan. Afghanistan’s only Olympic medals, a pair of bronzes, came from it, too.
content: TOKYO — In the sand-swept alleys of Niamey, the capital of one of the world’s poorest nations, Niger, they spin kick. In the Azraq refugee camp in Jordan, crowded with Syrians who fled civil war, they scissor kick. And in the slums of Thailand, where martial arts offer a tantalizing path out of poverty, they deliver the chopping ax kick that helps make taekwondo the most explosive of the combat sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carla Correa and Maggie Astor
title: Jordan Chiles is having an off day.
description: Chiles had been the only U.S. team member to avoid a major mistake in the past year. That changed on Sunday.
content: One question on many gymnastics fans’ minds was how well Jordan Chiles would fare in qualifications: Would she move on to the all-around or event finals, or would she be shut out because of gymnastics’ two-per-country rule?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: A Son of Tokyo Wins Skateboarding’s First Gold
description: Yuto Horigome won gold in the men’s street competition only eight miles from where he grew up, and after Nyjah Huston fell four times in a row.
content: TOKYO — With its street-riding roots, youthful vibe and full immersion into culture of all kinds, skateboarding was invited to the Olympics because its global reach could no longer be denied.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Toyota Led on Clean Cars. Now Critics Say It Works to Delay Them.
description: The auto giant bet on hydrogen power, but as the world moves toward electric the company is fighting climate regulations in an apparent effort to buy time.
content: The Toyota Prius hybrid was a milestone in the history of clean cars, attracting millions of buyers worldwide who could do their part for the environment while saving money on gasoline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Mr. President, You’re Just Plain Wrong on Voter Suppression
description: Black people need their voting rights protected. The president won't go all-out to help them.
content: Before I turn to President Biden’s historic failure to protect voting rights, a couple of stipulations must be made.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Warzel
title: The Great Outdoors Is Giving Way to the Great Indoors
description: Covid-19 isn't the only reason to wear a mask in the West.
content: MISSOULA, Mont. — “I wouldn’t go out without an N95 mask,” an oncology nurse told me the other day. She wasn’t referring to Covid-19 protections. Cases here remain quite low. I’m vaccinated. Besides, I wasn’t planning to be indoors. It was for the smoke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Sunisa Lee’s complex bars routine puts her in top spot after her rotation.
description: Lee, in the uneven bars, has one event where she’s a favorite even above Simone Biles.
content: No one in the world does an uneven bars routine as complex as Sunisa Lee’s, and she needs a mind-blowing amount of precision to perform it without smacking the bars by mistake and falling — or just falling because she missed grabbing the bars after a release move.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: No. 1 seed Ashleigh Barty is eliminated from the women’s tennis tournament.
description: Her ouster left Naomi Osaka, Japan’s biggest star this Olympics, as the top seed in women’s singles before her first match even began.
content: Naomi Osaka of Japan won her first match as a rare athlete to light an Olympic cauldron, but Ashleigh Barty of Australia is out of the Olympic singles tennis tournament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean and Yagazie Emezi
title: The Fisherwomen, Chevron and the Leaking Pipe
description: Big Oil has a filthy legacy in the Niger Delta region of Nigeria. One prominent environmentalist said: “They are moving out and leaving all the mess behind.”
content: GBARAMATU, Nigeria — When the tide rose under the rickety wooden house-on-stilts of Onitsha Joseph, a fisherwoman who lives above the twisting rivers of the Niger Delta in southern Nigeria, it brought a slick of crude oil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Pelosi Appoints Kinzinger to Panel Scrutinizing Jan. 6
description: The selection of Representative Adam Kinzinger for the special committee adds a second Republican who has been an unsparing critic of former President Donald J. Trump.
content: WASHINGTON — Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Sunday appointed Representative Adam Kinzinger to the special committee investigating the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol, adding a second Republican who is a forceful critic of former President Donald J. Trump to the panel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: Simone Manuel and the U.S. win bronze in the 4x100-meter freestyle relay.
description: Manuel swam the anchor leg for the United States in the relay.
content: Follow our live coverage of swimming at the Tokyo Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: Rescuing China’s Muzzled Past, One Footnote at a Time
description: In a two-volume tome, the independent historian Yu Ruxin explains the crucial role of the military in Mao’s stormy Cultural Revolution.
content: For decades, Yu Ruxin, a businessman turned independent historian, scoured used book stalls across China for frayed, yellowing documents about the Cultural Revolution, a decade of mass political upheaval unleashed by Mao Zedong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias
title: Facebook’s Next Target: The Religious Experience
description: The company is intensifying formal partnerships with faith groups across the United States and shaping the future of religious experience.
content: Months before the megachurch Hillsong opened its new outpost in Atlanta, its pastor sought advice on how to build a church in a pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Fauci Wants to Make Vaccines for the Next Pandemic Before It Hits
description: If funded, a government program costing several billion dollars could develop “prototype” vaccines to protect against 20 families of viruses.
content: In one sense, the world got lucky with the new coronavirus. By sheer chance, scientists just happened to have spent years studying coronaviruses, developing exactly the tools needed to make Covid vaccines as soon as the virus’s genetic sequence was published.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson and Michelle Mishina Kunz
title: For U.S. Lifters, It’s Fly, Then Clean and Jerk
description: Weight lifting officials in the United States are hoping an unusual pre-Olympic camp in Hawaii, capped by last-minute trips to Japan, will pay off in medals.
content: TOKYO — It is the travel version of a weight lifting attempt: months of preparation, a few moments to set oneself, a brief burst of all-out effort and, hopefully, a winning result.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 25, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 25, 2021.
content: An article on Page 8 this weekend about a staging of “Don Giovanni” refers incorrectly to the orchestra MusicAeterna’s recent activities at the Salzburg Festival in Austria. The ensemble did not play both Mozart’s “La Clemenza di Tito” and “Idomeneo”; it played only “La Clemenza di Tito.” The Freiburg Baroque Orchestra performed “Idomeneo.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Little Hedge Fund Taking Down Big Oil’
description: An activist investment firm won a shocking victory at Exxon Mobil. But can new directors really put the oil giant on a cleaner path?
content: The activist investment firm Engine No. 1 had been making the case since December that America’s most iconic oil company needed a directorial shake-up. Their argument was based on the idea that failing to plan for the impact of climate change could spell the demise of a business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carla Correa
title: What is honey used for? In gymnastics, it’s mostly the men using it.
description: It helps the gymnasts better grip the bars.
content: While the women competed in Tokyo, viewers watching NBC’s tape-delayed coverage of men’s gymnastics might have noticed honey bottles near the parallel bars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Biles launches to top vault spot even without widely anticipated move.
description: Simone Biles didn’t need the Yurchenko double pike vault during qualifying.
content: Everyone in the sport has been talking about when Simone Biles will attempt her breathtaking Yurchenko double pike vault at the Olympics. Turns out, it wasn’t during qualifying. And even without it, she did well enough to slide into first place on the vault after her turn.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Women’s gymnastics kicks off in Tokyo. Follow our live blog here.
description: Follow our live blog coverage of the gymnastics competition here.
content: Follow our live blog coverage of the gymnastics competition here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: An Iranian defector beats an Iranian in taekwondo.
description: Kimia Alizadeh was a star in Iran for winning bronze in 2016, but she left the country in 2020 and is now part of a refugee team.
content: In 2016, she became a teenage hero in her home country after becoming the first woman to win an Olympic medal for Iran. On Sunday, Kimia Alizadeh was a defector, part of a refugee team, with a draw pitting her against an Iranian opponent.
source.name: The New York Times

title: In Nagorno-Karabakh, Land Mines, Bulldozers and Lingering Tensions
description: Despite the hurdles, territory seized by Azerbaijan from Armenia in last year’s war is being transformed with breathtaking speed.
content: KELBAJAR, Azerbaijan — The medieval monastery walls are masked with camouflage netting. Machine-gun nests line the courtyard under a fluttering Russian flag. Cannons mounted on armored vehicles guard the mountainside where tour buses used to park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Soccer Team Was Lone Bright Spot in West Bank Village. Virus Took That, Too.
description: Despite a fan base of just 1,400 people, the Wadi al-Nis club was a perennial West Bank powerhouse. But the team — most of whose players are related — could not defeat the coronavirus.
content: WADI AL-NIS, West Bank — The bleachers were mostly empty, the coach was nowhere to be found, and the players were dejected as they suffered another lopsided defeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Bryson DeChambeau and Jon Rahm drop out of golf after testing positive.
description: The last two U.S. Open winners tested positive for the coronavirus as part of normal procedures for all athletes heading to Tokyo for the Olympics.
content: The men’s golf tournament at the Olympics will begin on Thursday without either of the last two U.S. Open winners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dylan Loeb McClain
title: Steven Weinberg, Groundbreaking Nobelist in Physics, Dies at 88
description: His discoveries deepened understanding of the basic forces at play in the universe, and he took general readers back to its dawn in his book “The First Three Minutes.”
content: Steven Weinberg, a theoretical physicist who discovered that two of the universe’s forces are really the same, for which he was awarded the Nobel Prize, and who helped lay the foundation for the development of the Standard Model, a theory that classifies all known elementary particles in the universe, making it one of the most important breakthroughs in physics in the 20th century, died on Friday in a hospital in Austin, Texas. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: It’s a 2-Team A.L. East Race. The Yankees Aren’t One of Them.
description: In another brutal loss for the Yankees, the Red Sox won, 5-4, despite Domingo German having started the eighth inning without having allowed a hit or a run.
content: BOSTON — Imagine if all the baseball we’ve seen this season had never been played. If you root for the Yankees, especially after another humbling weekend at Fenway Park, you might like that idea: Wipe it all away and start fresh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: What to watch for in swimming at the Olympics.
description: Swimming dominates the first week of the games. Expect some familiar faces and some new ones, many of them Americans including Katie Ledecky, on the medals stand.
content: Follow our live coverage of swimming at the Tokyo Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni and Eric Lipton
title: Leaders in Cryptocurrency Industry Move to Curb the Highest-Risk Trades
description: The moves would reduce the size of the bets that investors can make by drastically cutting the maximum leverage offered.
content: Two of the world’s most popular cryptocurrency exchanges announced on Sunday that they would curb a type of high-risk trading that has been blamed in part for sharp fluctuations in the value of Bitcoin and the casino-like atmosphere on such platforms globally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: U.S. men’s basketball, looking for a fresh start, loses to France instead.
description: After losing two exhibitions in Las Vegas, the U.S. men’s team lost its first game of the Olympics. Still, the Americans are a heavy favorite.
content: SAITAMA, Japan — The United States men’s basketball team fell to France, 83-76, in its opening game of the Olympics on Sunday night at Saitama Super Arena, remaining on unsteady footing after taking a rocky path to Tokyo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Nancy Mace Called Herself a ‘New Voice’ for the G.O.P. Then She Pivoted.
description: Her shift reflects how rank-and-file Republicans — even those who may disagree with him — have decided it is too perilous to openly challenge former President Donald J. Trump.
content: MOUNT PLEASANT, S.C. — Representative Nancy Mace had just delivered the kind of red-meat remarks that would ordinarily thrill the Republican voters in attendance here on a recent sweltering evening, casually comparing liberal Democrats to terrorists — the “Hamas squad,” she called them — and railing against their “socialist” spending plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock and Muktita Suhartono
title: No Longer ‘Hidden Victims,’ Children Are Dying as Virus Surges in Indonesia
description: Hundreds have died from Covid-19 in recent weeks, many of them under the age of 5. National leaders face mounting criticism that they have been unprepared.
content: Hundreds of children in Indonesia have died from the coronavirus in recent weeks, many of them under age 5, a mortality rate greater than that of any other country and one that challenges the idea that children face minimal risk from Covid-19, doctors say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson and Eduardo Medina
title: Rodney Alcala, the ‘Dating Game’ Serial Killer, Dies
description: A longhaired photographer who lured women by offering to take their picture, Mr. Alcala, 77, had been convicted of five murders in Orange County, Calif., and two in New York, all in the 1970s.
content: Rodney Alcala, who was known as the “Dating Game Killer” and was convicted in the murders of six women and one girl in the 1970s, died on Saturday at a hospital in Kings County, Calif. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher
title: Disinformation for Hire, a Shadow Industry, Is Quietly Booming
description: Back-alley firms meddle in elections and promote falsehoods on behalf of clients who can claim deniability, escalating our era of unreality.
content: In May, several French and German social media influencers received a strange proposal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: New York Has $2.7 Billion for Rent Relief. Many Have Yet to Receive Aid.
description: The program, designed to prevent mass evictions, has gotten off to a slow start, advocates said. And the end of the state’s eviction moratorium looms.
content: When New York launched a sweeping rent relief program in June, the aim was to safeguard the state’s recovery from the pandemic by keeping tens of thousands of people who fell behind on rent out of financial ruin and in their homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carla Correa
title: Here’s what to watch for from the U.S. gymnastics team.
description: The first day of women’s gymnastics is a marathon: The qualification rounds, which decide which teams and athletes will vie for medals, last about 12 hours.
content: The first day of women’s gymnastics is a marathon: The qualification rounds, which decide which teams and athletes will vie for medals, last about 12 hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carla Correa
title: How to watch in the United States.
description: Get ready for an all-nighter if you’d like to stream the gymnastics competition live in the U.S.
content: Follow our live coverage of swimming at the Tokyo Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katy Reckdahl and L. Kasimu Harris
title: How to Reopen a Festival City When a Virus Lurks: Very Anxiously
description: There’s a special uneasiness unique to cities like New Orleans, highly dependent on close, in-person contact.
content: NEW ORLEANS — Virgil Tiller is back to work on Thursday nights, playing his saxophone with the Stooges Brass Band at The Well, a small club located at the edge of the city’s Tremé neighborhood, about five blocks from the French Quarter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Landslide Kills 9 in Northern India and Destroys Bridge
description: Dramatic video showed boulders rolling down into a valley in Himachal Pradesh state in the Himalayas.
content: A landslide in northern India caused boulders to tumble down a mountain and strike a vehicle, killing at least nine people, many believed to be tourists, and destroying a bridge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: In Louisiana, Vaccine Misinformation Has Public Health Workers Feeling ‘Stuck’
description: Facing deep mistrust stoked by rampant conspiracy theories, local health officials are fighting for influence when the only sure strategy for beating back the virus is getting more people vaccinated.
content: SHREVEPORT, La. — Dr. Martha Whyte, the top public health official in the northwest corner of Louisiana, was sitting at the back of a City Council meeting here on a muggy day recently when she was called to the front of the room to respond to an attack on the coronavirus vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘We Could Not Find a Sign Pointing Us to Home Plate’s Former Home’
description: On a baseball pilgrimage in Brooklyn, how the Bronx inspired and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Gordon
title: After Two Decades in Music, Yola Expands Her Powers
description: Last year, the English powerhouse singer and songwriter was nominated for four Grammys. Now she’s returning with “Stand for Myself,” an album made on her own terms.
content: Calculus is hard. Parallel parking is hard. Meeting and working with people who don’t look like you — that’s a breeze. “It’s. Not. Hard,” the singer and songwriter Yola emphasized during a recent call, clapping her hands in between each word. “I literally came from another continent, and remedied it in six months. Even my manager, from remotely in England, found writers of color for me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: The Delta Variant Is the Symptom of a Bigger Threat: Vaccine Refusal
description: There are almost as many reasons for vaccine hesitancy and refusal as there are unvaccinated Americans. But this problem, not the variant, lies at the root of rising infection rates.
content: After an all too brief respite, the United States is again at a crossroads in the pandemic. The number of infections has ticked up — slowly at first, then swiftly — to 51,000 cases per day, on average, more than four times the rate a month ago. The country may again see overflowing hospitals, exhausted health care workers and thousands of needless deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Vaccines, Tokyo Olympics, Summer Camp: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Unbowed, Biles Keeps on Rising Five Years Later
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 25, 2021.
content: “At the end of the day, I’m such a huge athlete, but who am I? If you take off that mask, you know, who will I be? I’m still trying to find that out.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: At Surfing’s Olympic Debut, Routine Waves and No Regrets
description: For competitors who didn’t expect to see surfing become an Olympic sport, not even a subpar surf could spoil the vibe.
content: ICHINOMIYA, Japan — Like most surfers, Stephanie Gilmore of Australia never expected to see surfing in the Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Meet Olympic Surfing’s Wave Whisperer
description: Kurt Korte does not control the waves for the Games’ debut surfing competition. His job is to predict when the best ones will arrive.
content: ICHINOMIYA, Japan — Surfing is the only event at the Summer Olympics without a precise, predetermined schedule. It might happen today, but maybe not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Medal ceremonies at Tokyo Games require social distance and limits on not wearing a mask.
description: The International Olympic Committee announced a modification to medal awarding procedures after concern that athletes were openly violating strict coronavirus protocols.
content: It is a quintessential Olympic moment. After every event, after the Olympic champion’s national anthem is played, the winners of the silver and bronze medals are welcomed to the top step of the medals stand. There, they pose — together with the winner — for a photograph.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh and Victor Mather
title: Chase Kalisz wins the first U.S. gold medal in Tokyo.
description: Kalisz and Jay Litherland went 1-2 in the 400-meter individual medley.
content: TOKYO — After an opening day without a medal, the United States swim team got two in the first event of the day on Sunday. By lunchtime, Americans had collected a half dozen at the pool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Broadcaster Apologizes for ‘Inappropriate’ Images Aired During Olympic Parade
description: The South Korean broadcaster MBC showed photographs associating pizza with Italy, Chernobyl with Ukraine and Count Dracula with Romania in its coverage of the opening ceremony.
content: For television broadcasters worldwide, the parade of nations during the opening of the Olympics can be an exercise in diplomacy and global awareness, with media outlets resorting to trivia nuggets, athlete profiles and geopolitical musings to fill airtime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $500,000 or Less
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: She celebrated as if she had won a gold. Except she hadn’t.
description: Moments after crossing the finish line of the women’s cycling road race Annamiek van Vleuten was told she had placed second.
content: It was the crowning achievement of her cycling career. Except it wasn’t.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: The Week in Business: Rethinking Office Plans
description: A new spike in coronavirus cases, driven by the highly infectious Delta variant, rattled investors and companies last week.
content: A new spike in coronavirus cases, driven by the highly infectious Delta variant, rattled investors and companies last week. On Monday, fear over what a rise in cases, mostly among the unvaccinated, would mean for the global economic recovery drove the worst decline for the S&P 500 in months. But on Tuesday, stocks bounced back. The recent outbreaks are also prompting executives to rethink their plans for reopening offices. Apple, for example, said it would delay its plans to return to the office by at least a month, to Oct. 1 at the earliest. But not all companies have come to the same conclusion. Morgan Stanley’s chief legal officer urged the bank’s outside law firms to call their lawyers back to the office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Oksana Chusovitina, at 46, gets a standing ovation at her last Olympics.
description: The gymnast who competes for Uzbekistan has participated in eight Games.
content: After Oksana Chusovitina, a gymnast competing for Uzbekistan, finished her practice session last week here at the Tokyo Games, gymnast after gymnast lined up to pose with her for a selfie. She is royalty in the sport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Why Do Parents Keep Hearing About the Microbiome?
description: Some companies are marketing baby soaps, lotions, supplements and more as being ‘biome-friendly.’ But there’s reason to be skeptical.
content: Our bodies house an extraordinarily vast collection of bacteria and other microorganisms — so many, in fact, that scientists now estimate there may be just as many bacteria in our bodies as human cells.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah, Daniel E. Slotnik and Jesus Jiménez
title: Require vaccines? In parts of the U.S., even mask mandates are a bridge too far.
description: As the Delta variant of the coronavirus spreads, a debate is raging among government officials and business leaders not only about requiring vaccinations, but about reimposing indoor mask rules.
content: As the Delta variant of the coronavirus spreads through unvaccinated populations in the United States, many municipalities, colleges and businesses are weighing not only whether to require vaccinations but also whether to reimpose indoor mask mandates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: The Salzburg Festival Opens in Search of Elusive Peace
description: Salzburg is back, opening with a week of Ouverture Spirituelle concerts that project the ideal of paradise on the pandemonium of reality.
content: SALZBURG, Austria — “What is peace?” a singer asks in Latin at the start of Klaus Huber’s “Quod Est Pax?” The orchestra responds with a wandering, spectral sound that underscores the question, as it is asked again and considered from different angles, until the instruments erupt in a disorderly mass as if to answer: Peace is not a pleasant tune.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carla Correa
title: MyKayla Skinner had a long road to the Olympics.
description: Her career is ending at the Toyko Games.
content: Several months ago, MyKayla Skinner was hospitalized for pneumonia after contracting the coronavirus. Now, her long career — in both elite and college gymnastics — is ending at the Tokyo Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: 5 Dead in Hamptons Crash That Is Blamed on Speeding
description: A driver veered into the opposite lane and struck a car head-on in one of at least three fatal crashes in and around the city on Saturday.
content: A group of friends were traveling on a two-lane highway in the Hamptons over the weekend when a speeding driver veered across the dividing line and hit them head-on, killing four people and himself, the police said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Yuto Horigome wins the first skateboarding medal as Nyjah Huston falters.
description: Horigome won gold in the men’s street competition, just eight miles from where he grew up. But Huston, the U.S. star, fell four times in a row in a disappointing performance.
content: Skateboarding’s entry into the Olympics evolved into a tense can-you-top-this exhibition in the men’s street competition, as one world-class skateboarder after another did nuanced variations of tricks off the park’s biggest feature, a 12-stair drop with three different rails.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: In ‘You Are Here,’ Dancing and Splashing at Lincoln Center
description: A selection of New Yorkers reflecting on their pandemic experiences became part of this piece, conceived and choreographed by Andrea Miller.
content: As dance regains its footing in the performing arts world this summer — gradually and with grit and the best of intentions — putting on a show carries a different weight. How exactly must the show go on? Who shares responsibility and who gets the credit? If the past year and a half has taught us anything, it’s to pay attention to those on the edges, to recalibrate just who and what are essential. Art and artists, certainly. But it takes more than artists to make art happen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh
title: The Pandemic Ruined Third Grade. Can Summer School Make Up for It?
description: After months of remote learning, Zion Graham is in summer school. But can a six-week program make up for his lost year?
content: GREENSBORO, N.C. — In second grade, Zion Graham bounded to school. He loved math. His favorite book was about a slow turtle who took all day to get dressed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson, Clay Risen and Eduardo Medina
title: Bob Moses, Crusader for Civil Rights and Math Education, Dies at 86
description: Mr. Moses developed a reputation for extraordinary calm in the face of violence as he helped to register thousands of voters and trained a generation of activists in Mississippi in the early 1960s.
content: Bob Moses, a soft-spoken pioneer of the civil rights movement who faced relentless intimidation and brutal violence to register Black voters in Mississippi in the 1960s, and who later started a national organization devoted to teaching math as a means to a more equal society, died on Sunday at his home in Hollywood, Fla. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Known for Paradoxes
description: Tommy Pauly plays a gig.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to Tommy Pauly, who is making his debut today with this pun-packed Monday puzzle. The theme is a delight, and I enjoyed the slow-motion revealer that started at 1A and ended at the final across clue (68A).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gary Phillips
title: A Baseball Nomad Is Still on the Move
description: Edwin Jackson played on 14 M.L.B. teams, a record. His next (and potentially last) stop is Tokyo for the Olympics.
content: Edwin Jackson was still in diapers the first time he moved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: The Olympics have begun.
content: The Games opened on Friday to a sea of empty seats, and a somber opening ceremony that tried to project a world moving on from the worst of Covid-19. Naomi Osaka, Japan’s most famous athlete, lit the Olympic caldron.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Ellis
title: April Ross and Alix Klineman begin with a win in beach volleyball.
description: Ross is seeking gold after winning bronze and silver in the last two Olympics.
content: TOKYO — April Ross and Alix Klineman, an American power duo in beach volleyball, started their Olympics with a win on Sunday, defeating the Chinese team of Xue Chen and Wang Xinxin, 21-17, 21-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Naomi Osaka Returns to the Stage, on Her Terms
description: After the tumult over her skipping the French Open and Wimbledon, she returned to light the cauldron for what may very well end up as the Osaka Games.
content: TOKYO — In the early afternoon Sunday, Naomi Osaka walked onto the center court at the Ariake Tennis Park to begin her quest for an Olympic gold medal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: America’s Rugby Sevens Teams Try to Restart Their Prepandemic Roll
description: The men’s and women’s U.S. teams were ranked second in the world in 2019 and eager for a medal in Tokyo. Then the pandemic stopped them in their tracks.
content: CHULA VISTA, Calif. — Momentum is a funny thing in sports. It can crystallize seemingly out of nowhere and vanish just as easily.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: ‘It’s not going to be good.’ Fauci sounds alarm over low vaccination rates fueling Covid surge.
description: With only about half of Americans vaccinated, Dr. Anthony Fauci and other current and former health officials vigorously pressed the case on Sunday that inoculations were the best way to stem a tide of new Covid cases.
content: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, President Biden’s chief medical adviser, warned on Sunday that the coronavirus pandemic is now “going in the wrong direction” in the United States because too many Americans are still choosing not to get vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Kozol
title: The Enduring Whimsy and Wonderment of Eric Carle
description: The beloved children’s author and illustrator died in May. But his irrepressible spirit lives on in his books.
content: I’ve been looking at a letter from Eric Carle, written in a frail script in 2019, in which he told me that his health was failing. It was the last of many letters, some typed, others handwritten, he had sent me through the years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Surfing at the Olympics: What to Watch For
description: Surfing is making its debut at the 2020 Olympics. The event is being held about 60 miles away from Tokyo at Tsurigasaki Beach.
content: The world’s best surfers will be converging at the Olympics for the first time. They’re poised to put on a good show … as long as the waves cooperate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Child Tax Credit Payments Have Begun. Should You Opt Out?
description: While the payments in advance of tax season are a welcome relief for many families, there may be reasons for others to decline the money, for now.
content: Millions of families with children have probably noticed that their bank accounts looked a little more flush this month because they received an extra injection of cash from the government — up to $300 for each child.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Here’s how to make sense of the women’s gymnastics competitions.
description: Women’s gymnastics is a marquee sport at the Summer Olympics, but otherwise doesn’t get much attention outside a dedicated group of fans.
content: Women’s gymnastics is a marquee sport at the Summer Olympics, but otherwise doesn’t get much attention outside a dedicated group of fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Simone Biles starts Olympics with a floor exercise that isn’t up to her usual standards.
description: In her third tumbling pass, her momentum caused her to fly out of bounds and off the competition floor. It was one of her worst floor performances of the year.
content: Simone Biles usually owns the floor exercise. She has been great in the event ever since she was very young, back when some people mistakenly thought she would end up to be a specialist on the floor and the vault — and never an all-arounder. Those naysayers are probably hiding in a corner now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Ward, Lazaro Gamio, Larry Buchanan, Bedel Saget, Niko Koppel, Mark McKeague, Or Fleisher, Tessa Barton, Peter Whidden and Alexandre Devaux
title: Australia Dominates Again in the Women’s 4x100 Freestyle Relay
description: Australia won the 4x100 freestyle by more than 3 seconds over the United States. Here’s the meter-by-meter analysis of how they did it.
content: Australia won the 4x100 freestyle by more than 3 seconds over the United States. Here’s the meter-by-meter analysis of how they did it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tokyo Olympics on Sunday: Time to Go Big
description: Because holding back now helps nobody.
content: Because holding back now helps nobody.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Vaccine Mandate Is Not the Federal Government’s Role, Psaki Says
description: Jen Psaki, the White House press secretary, said on Friday that mandating Covid-19 vaccinations was an appropriate decision for private sector companies, institutions and local communities.
content: Jen Psaki, the White House press secretary, said on Friday that mandating Covid-19 vaccinations was an appropriate decision for private sector companies, institutions and local communities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: We have recipes for the slow days of summer: mushroom chicharrón tacos, salt and pepper shrimp rolls, and more.
content: Good morning. We’re moving into the slowest of the slow days, deepest summer, everything languid, not much happening at all. Tomatoes are ripening. Corn’s growing tall. I’m getting reports from cookouts and barbecues, clambakes, fish fries, oyster feeds and picnics — all those spirited endeavors we missed last year, sheltering from the pandemic in our pods. I hope your weekend was filled with them, with the joy of gathering with others in the presence of food and drink.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Should Big States Be Broken Up?
description: Readers take sides pro and con on a controversial question. Also: Proof of vaccination at cultural venues; Black colleges; student loan forgiveness; decluttering; Amazon's business model.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
